reviewText: "See No Evil" is a horror film whose exceptional style is overshadowed by an incredibly preposterous story, one that can't even be redeemed by suspension of disbelief. I've seen poorly produced teen slasher films with more plausible ideas than this, and I should think that even the fans of those kinds of films--the ones who appreciate depictions of senseless killing and gruesome gore effects--will come away feeling swindled. It's an idea that manages to water down already inconceivable horror movie cliches, including the promiscuous teens, the well-intentioned but ultimately useless cops, and the background story involving harsh mental and physical abuse. I left the theater thinking I had seen a movie made with a half finished script and the rest was just the director winging it. Whoever saw the final cut of this film and gave it the go ahead must have been half asleep.It's established right from the start that World Wrestling Entertainment produced this. Vince McMahon himself was the executive producer. I wonder why they had to get involved at all, considering they did nothing to enhance the film. Even the casting of one of their own--Glen Jacobs (better known as Kane) as the menacing serial killer Jacob Goodnight--wasn't enough to make a difference. Yes, he did look the part; his broad, commanding physical presence meshed well with the ghastly makeup effects, which included sharp, pointed teeth, a pulsating wound on the back of his head, and thick, green fingernails. Looking at him is enough to make one terrified, and in that sense, the movie "succeeds." However, they just as easily could have cast some unknown bodybuilder. This is not a role that requires a stellar performance; it seemed that the only requirement was the ability to breathe heavily and walk around like a stalker. And let's not forget that Kane has exactly one line of dialogue in this film. This means that attention to delivery and intonation was unnecessary. (How much easier can it get?)Truth be told, the film in and of itself was unnecessary, presenting a blood soaked story that ineffectively combines murder and religious fanaticism. It begins when two police officers arrive at a dilapidated house in response to complaints of screaming. They enter completely unprepared, both mentally and physically. They hear a repetitive religious song singing the praises of children emanating from a distant room. Upon entering, they find a young woman with her eyes gouged out. That's when Goodnight appears. Naturally, the rookie cop is killed instantly, receiving the swift slash of an axe directly down the center of his head. The other cop--Williams (Steven Vidler)--manages to escape, but not before his left hand is chopped off. He subdues Goodnight with a direct shot to the head. Because this is a horror film, I won't bother with trying to understand why that didn't kill him. However, I did find it baffling that he wasn't taken away, either in cuffs or a body bag.Why did I find this baffling? Well, the fact that he reemerges four years later is a big clue, as is the fact that the filmmakers never once tried to explain how he was able to escape from police custody (if he was even in it). But the fact remains that he's still alive, hiding within the walls of an abandoned hotel called the Blackwell. And now, he has a fresh batch of victims at his disposal. A small group of detention center inmates, led by the one-armed Williams, is transported to the rundown, filthy hotel to participate in a renovation program. They include: Richie (Craig Horner), Kira (Samantha Noble), Michael (Luke Pegler), Zoe (Rachael Taylor), and Tye (Michael J. Pagan), just to name a few.The idea is for them to perform community service in exchange for time taken off of their sentences. In essence, the hotel becomes their new prison, each person designated a room in the upper floors of the hotel. I'd like you to try and follow this logic with me: a group of convicted felons--some of which are violent and antisocial--are dropped off at a location without a security staff and with no sure fire way to keep them from escaping. Furthermore, they're surrounded by various items that can be used as weapons, such as shards of glass, stakes of rotted wood, broken pipes, and firefighter axes. I'm sorry, but I fail to see how this makes any sense. It doesn't help that Williams, a man who knows a thing or two about the legal system, is apparently unaware of the group's background information (at one point, he confesses that he knew nothing of the relationship Kira and Michael shared, a violent, drug filled relationship that wrongfully landed Kira in the detention center).But I guess none of that matters; apparently, someone made it a rule that gore and violence take precedence over story when making a horror film. One by one, the inmates fall victim to Goodnight's fury. Those moments usually include him using his forefinger to pluck eyes directly out of the sockets, supposedly so he can "see the sin" within them. It's never adequately explained, but it seems that a devoutly religious woman, who would regularly lock him in a cage, raised him to believe that he was the Hand of God, meant to do His work by killing "wicked" people. We get hints of his upbringing in quick, random flashes of memory, most likely in an attempt to gain sympathy from the audience. But the fact that he was written as the killer makes the entire subplot meaningless. In horror movies, you're not supposed to root for the bad guy, no matter how difficult his childhood was.But I found that I couldn't root for the victims, either, and I didn't feel remorse over their deaths. How could I when they did such stupid things, like wander around for lost treasure, or venture into a closed off area of the hotel to smoke pot? None of the inmates in this film are good people; even the halfway decent ones--the ones that show respect and behave pleasantly--leave a lot to be desired. It's never a good thing to leave a movie feeling emotionally bankrupt, especially when lives are forcefully taken. But that's exactly how I felt leaving "See No Evil," and I recommend anyone in search of quality horror movie entertainment to steer clear of it. It's a cheap, underachieving waste of time that deserves none of the accolades it will most likely get from slasher film fanatics.
summary: "See No Evil"? I See No Point

reviewText: Stop me if you've heard this one before: we have this big ol' Labyrinth, or decaying Hotel, or spooky old House abandoned years ago by a family whose son slaughtered a) his big sister who flaunted those pink-polka dot skivvies one time too many; b)pretty much the entire block, except for this really smart kiddo in a nuclear-powered wheelchair; c) the whole school---on Prom Night! d) an entire mechanized division from Fort Bragg.Anyway, some say the Place is Haunted. Some say it's just rundown, needs to be cleaned up, maybe it can be rented out. So: you get a bunch of derelict mutton-headed kids down from Juvie Hall, give 'em shovels and brooms and toilet ducks, and dispatch them into the gaping maw of our little localized Entrance to Hell.Slaughter commences, interspersed by dialogue we really don't care about. Roll credits (with some shrieking nu-metal song). Sit in the theater chairs that don't go back far enough (so all your joints are achey by the end of the flick), see the half-lights come up all runny the color of syrup, and hear departing theatergoers making their retreat over the sticky popcorn-y floors. For some reason, hearing some guy squetch-squetching out of the theater, his soles sticking to the spilled coagulating pop on the floor, makes me think of lingering futile death.That's it. "See no Evil" is like one of those "don't blink or you'll miss it" little dirtwater dullsville towns: it's there, you dig it, there are a couple of cool kills, Kane's got a big gaping hole in the back of his little bald noggin with worms wriggling around which is kinda cool, and then this forgettable flick goes down into the darkness of the Id with all its cousins.Sad thing is, with a few tweaks the movie coulda been a contender. Alright, this is what I would have done with "see no evil" if I had been the screenwriter to do the gig, wining & dining myself by some lagoon-sized swimming pool high in the Hollywood hills slurping down Fuzzy Navels and Mai Tais and a wild ride of drinks with little plastic doohickeys floating in them while starlets unleashed Holy Jihad in an attempt to occupy my casting couch.Where were we? Oh yeah, look: Kane does just fine cutting a swathe of destruction with hammer and fist and nasty-serrated-edged grappling hook thingy, which proves the guy can't be all that bad because he's at least creative. When was the last time you saw The Shape or Jason come up with a double-bladed serrated edge grappling hook thingy? Yeah! You can hook your prey, relish their agony and whiney screams, *and* drag them to ya, where you can get Medieval on `em.So no fault to Kane, who owns every nano-second of his screentime. It's just that---well, this flick doesn't have to be so, um, complex. Look: we come to this kind of movie for slaughter. Feed the prey in through Gate A, have Kane stomping around in spandex through Gate B, gore & charnel & carnage for the rest of the 90 minutes of running time. We don't need no steenkin' story: mega-death is story sufficient unto the day.Next, Kane should shuck the duds. Look, the guy is Kane, he chops the arm off a cop and that's just for appetizers. He doesn't need to wear clothes. He could wear, say, a big red jumpsuit with "K" emblazoned on the front in cloth-of-gold, or a gasmask and a diaper, or maybe just a plastic bag. He's Kane! He's gotta say "I'm gonna come in through the wall and kill every last one of ya and I don't need to roll in walka wear."Also, Kane needed to smash through more walls to get to his prey. Smashing through walls is classic psycho behavior: loads of laughs. More of that, por favor.And the silly throw-axe just didn't work for me, sorry. Points for creativity, as noted above, but lose it. Kane doesn't need complex: he needs to wield a big battle axe, like a dwarf from Lord of the Rings would wield on the field of Battle. And split more skulls. And maybe scalp the girls, and wear their faces. And maybe put a few of their heads on stakes.See, until directors are comfy with the premise behind this kind of flick: WE COME TO SEE THE SLAUGHTER!---we'll never get a decent splatter movie. Put Kane in a thong, give him a chainsaw, air-drop him down into a hockey rink, and feed victims in through a trough, have Mastodon do the soundtrack.Jeez, even the Romans knew how to do this kinda thing right, and they didn't even have THX or Dolby or HDTV.The Technology is ready, the Screen is ready, the Audience is ready. Let's get it on!JSG

reviewText: Honestly going into this film I expected the worst, but I have to say See No Evil really wasn't a bad movie. Is this a classic in the genre?No not at all. It's not Tobe Hooper's The Texas Chainsaw Massacre or John Carpenter's Halloween and in time I'm sure See No Evil will probably be forgotten about.See No Evil may not inspire a generation of filmmakers, but for what it's worth it was enjoyable. There are flaws with the movie. The biggest problem being the lack of likable characters, outside of maybe Christina Vidal and Samantha Noble's characters the rest weren't very likable or interesting for that matter. And even they weren't developed at all.Sure a lot of horror movies like See No Evil don't have a lot of character development, but it doesn't seem like the makers even tired. The characters are as thin as they paper they were written on.Dave Madigan who writes for the WWE was the writer for See No Evil and while I don't think his script was terrible it wasn't very good.There were some decent ideas, but they just weren't fleshed out.Gregory Dark really doesn't try anything to make his movie standout. The tone of the movie could have been darker. But Dark went from porn to directing videos for Britney Spears, not sure if he is the right choice for something really dark.See No Evil would have been better off if it went down the TCM or Devil's Rejects route and aimed to disturb.It did have that vibe just a bit, but not enough. While Gregory Dark didn't do a bad job he does it by the books. Some of scenes work well at the end of the day it's nothing special.One of the major problems was the editing; you know what is described as "MTV Style Editing?" See No Evil has some of that.My biggest complaint is the way Glen "Kane" Jacobs was used. He is a big guy and could have been really creepy, which he sort of was only for the fact the guy is intimidating.But he wasn't used to his full potential. Bottom line is this, See No Evil may not go down as one of the greats, but it really wasn't a bad horror flick.I'm surprised at all the negative reviews; not sure what everyone was expecting.Again See No Evil isn't a classic horror movie by any means, but it's fairly well done and enjoyable. You can find a lot better movies out there, but you can also find a lot worse.
summary: See No Evil actually wasn't that bad.

reviewText: Who I Am: A life-long wrestling fan. A life-long horror film fan (including slashers; I grew up watching A Nightmare on Elm Street). The reason you need to know my background is because most people watching this movie will probably not like it as much as I did. I am the perfect audience for this movie. Not only that, but I was fortunate enough to see the film at its premiere screening in Anaheim, CA in an auditorium with several WWE wrestlers and officials, including JBL, Mick Foley, Ricky Steamboat and Edge. It was an awesome atmosphere and most people watching this film will not have that kind of "vibe." With those warnings out of the way--my review:About the Film: See No Evil is about a group of juvenile delinquents who are brought to an abandoned, burned-out hotel as part of a "community service" in order to reduce their sentences. Hiding in the hotel is a psychopathic murderer (WWE Superstar Kane) who proceeds to murder the group--the kids and their adult chaperones--one by one in classic slasher fashion.The thing that sets See No Evil apart from other slasher films is how gory it is. Now, I know you're saying: "All slasher films are very gory"--and that's basically true. But See No Evil is gorier than almost any other movie that I've ever seen. It is very, very, very gory (scenes include eyes being gouged out on camera, limbs being sliced off, people having objects stuffed down their throats, etc.). While many people will find the film scary, I thought it wasn't very much so; just gory.The plot line is fairly straight-forward. It gets to the killing very quickly, and when it does, the rest of the movie is basically about Kane hunting victims. There isn't much character development. This is not "refined" cinema in any sense of the word, except that the film is very good technically. The murder sequences all look fairly realistic, which adds to the gore factor.Kane, himself, has very little acting in the movie. Unless I counted wrong, he has all of two or three lines of dialogue. Despite that, I thought he did a surprisingly strong job. There were a few scenes that relied on his facial expressions to convey the material, and Kane did not disappoint. He did as well as could have been hoped for.In all, this is certainly not a classic film (it was never meant to be), and among similar types of slasher films, it is decent and well-made, but not great. That said, it is an entertaining film, and fans of gore should be very satisfied with the variety of hack-scenes and how well they're presented. Fans of WWE should be happy to see Kane, and relieved to know that he does not embarrass himself or wrestling, but instead does a fine job. Wrestling fans who can tolerate shock-horror and gore should definitely see the film and horror fans who don't care about/like wrestling will have a decent time, but the general film-going populace without any particular love of wrestling or horror films is probably better off passing, here.This is a solid first effort from WWE Films. 3 Stars.
summary: A Decent, Very Gory Slasher Film; A Good First Effort For WWE

reviewText: This was the first offical movie to come from the film division of World Wrestling Entertainmet called "WWE Films" and it's approprate that when casting the starring role for a horror/scary movie that they went with WWE's resident monster in Kane.The story here is about a former cop put in charge of group of teenagers from juvenile prisions (four boys & four girls) are put together for a work release program, with one couple having a past together, to clean up the Blackwell Hotel which was heavily damaged in a fire & rotting for years afterwards.  As you would expect, each set of teenagers have their own personal agendas inside the hotel from having sex to doing drugs to looking for money to just trying to get out of the hotel.  What they didn't know though is that there is a giant killer in the building named Jacob Goodnight who lives there & always collects the eyes of his victims since he sees them as the window to the soul.  He really doesn't take kindly to people invading this territory & goes through a series of alarms & hidden areas to track the kids down while they try to fight for their own lives while in some cases, their own sin & personality traits comes back to haunt them.This movie was a horror flick similar to how Friday The 13th the sterotypical "monster" going after kids in a confined area. The part of the movie that kept it interesting that alot of horror movies don't do today was that you didn't know who was going to survive & the first kill really displayed that. Kane was very believeable in his role but anyone who watched him in WWE should know that this role came naturally.DVD extras include two sets of commentary including one with Kane, a "Making Of" featurette, a video package of Kane's career, all the WWE promotional spots for the movie, storyboard comparisions for certain scenes, and movie trailers.In the end, I thought it was a good "old school" slasher type movie that made people like Jason famous. reviewText: Among the variety of religious-based, over-used plot lines, See No Evil, still stands to rate a bit above the average "teen slasher film." So what can you expect to find here?So this brings me to the plot first...On the top tier it was an average joe plot. They used the whole overly religious mother idea, similar to the "Carrie" ordeal. I guess every serial killer needs a simple explanation....but either way, it sets up the film. We roll around on this plot for most of the movie, while they attempt to mix in a few other interesting elements to make it seem deeper than just a psycho killer, case-in-point. I must admit that it was a little bit more unpredictable than most films of this caliber, and that was something I definitely enjoyed.The set really worked to the film's advantage, and it fits right in there with all of the other old abandoned buildings that emit this grimy, creepy atmosphere willing to suck the life out of anyone who is to enter. The addition of the rotting homeless really tied in with the story and only added to the fear. This, combined with the excellent use of cinematic lighting really led the film in a direction that I didn't expect it to go. Surprisingly, they did a good job tying it all together and the director must've had some good experiences with technology in the past, because he pulled out some interesting tricks and well-crafted experiences.We see a bunch of new faces as far as acting is concerned, so there is a bit of new blood here. And with that, I guess you have to expect some follies, because I noticed quite a few forced scenes, but all-in-all it was believable. The only part I always struggle with is when the "good-guys" are on a winning streak, but never stand to finish what they started (ie. when the antagonist is down for the count, finish him off....don't just run away...) But I guess this can be expected in just about any teen slasher film.The "villain" worked out well, but I think that just a bit more could be done to enhance his look. Though, I guess it depends on how you look at it. He looked scary in the sense that he looked human, but not in the sense that he was disfigured or anything else that people usually find grotesquely uncomfortable. But however you look at it, I suppose it worked.As far as the death scenes go, they're pretty much your standard slasher film; a few new things, but mostly just lots of sharp, useful objects. It was pretty interesting how they made the death scenes ironic in relation to the characters, and that helped add some interest to the common downfall of the ill-advised young-adult. Not to mention that the gore in this movie was nearly exceptional. It was a bit more realistic than most films, so you can expect some gut-wrenching moments here.I think that if this was one of the original slasher movies, it has enough balls to be considered a classic. But since it's been mixed in with a plethora of other sub-standard films, it's going to fall short of our now high expectations. Still, it's a pretty good ride from start to finish, and the plot is thicker than just some punks getting their heads smashed in. With the excellent use of special effects make-up, it's a bit more of a gorefest than most films in this bracket.Overall, not too bad. I might add it to my collection, but I'll have to see what Christmas brings me. If you're a fan of the teen slasher or gorehound, it's a must rent, probably a must-buy. reviewText: The movie is wholly unoriginal.  It is directed like a porno, edited like a Marylin Manson video and scripted like the Halloween episode of One Tree Hill. The scariest part of this movie is that it got made. So is it terrible? Not really. Because Kane does a good job in this role. He is given little to work with and thrust into a ridiculously amateurish production, but he is used to that too. Kane menaces the screen convincingly, and adds a human element to this killing machine. The expressive head tilts he perfected under the mask give his character a feral element lacking in the Jasons and Micheals of the genre. He is given a little room to stretch as an actor as he recreates the "Vader turns on the Emporer" scene near the end. He does a marvelous job of it, leaving the audience wondering why they didn't use his range more.I hate to use classic as a comparison, but suffice to say that the premise stinks of being a poor man's cousin of Alfred Hitchcock's Psycho filed with generous doses of MTV styled quick cuts. Instead of Bates motel, you have Blackwell Hotel, together with the suggestion that it is the all domineering and crazed mother whose warped upbringing nurtured humanity's monster. Taking yet another swipe at religious zealots too, as flashbacks show the young psycho kid being tortured by a mom who cages him and the punishment dished out for looking at porn hence the title of the movie.Packed into the movie are the various fodder for him to maim and kill. Character development, or at least the attempt in trying to weave in a tale of revenge, seem to be abandoned halfway, as characters start to drop off like barflies. It doesn't take you too long to realize who's on which side, and who'll survive (according to horror slasher flick lore that the blondie and those having sex must die) given the clichés. Starring relative unknowns as a bunch of inmates sent to the Hotel to perform cleaning fatigues, it's a pity that most of them were not given glorious cinematic deaths in a movie like this.Perhaps with movies like "Hills Have Eyes," the "Saw" franchise, and "Hostel," we're all a bit jaded from the rehashed dark and dankly film sets and throwaway characters. There's nothing new presented in this movie, and is only made for Kane's fan base. Even then, with so little of their star seen in the flesh, they might as well be better off with his exploits in the wrestling ring.

reviewText: The WWE's Kane makes his movie debut as something he's relatively comfortable playing:  a monster of a man intent on pulverizing his victims.  Had writer Dan Madigan left out the backstory and just let gore fans feast on the actions of Jacob Goodnight (Kane), this film would have been a decent, above-average gore-fest.  However, there always has to be a reason for a killer molded in the form of Goodnight to exact his wicked fury on his victims.  In this case, Goodnight has been convinced by his mother that he's the "hand of God" and has to rid the world of the wicked, or at least pluck out their eyes.  We learn of this in flashbacks, full of jittery camera work, terror-inducing angles, and a little bit of gore.  These vignettes actually weigh the action of this flick down.  Also, the unlikeable-yet-well-groomed juvenile delinquents that Goodnight feasts on are less than stellar actors and actresses.  That's somewhat expected in a flick like this, but I kept getting the feeling that these kids were better suited for a SciFi Channel horror flick than a well-budgeted gore yarn such as "See No Evil."The juvi-hall kids end up in the abandoned Blackwell Hotel, supposedly there to clean up the place in order to get a month knocked off of their respective sentences.  When they get there, however, there's an angry, confused, seven foot tall, four hundred pound monster waiting for them.  They spend the rest of the flick running from him, outwitting him, hiding from him, and, in most cases, ending up on the business end of a large hook or axe.Many of the kills in this flick were executed rather well.  There are a couple of original kills (my favorite involving an animal rights girl) and a few tried and true ones as well.  Most of the gore is a mixture of CGI and old fashioned buckets of goo.  They come off looking pretty good overall.As stated before, the backstory and the victims weigh this flick down.  It's only eighty-four minutes long, so Kane has to get to business pretty quickly.  There are hints at "Texas Chainsaw Massacre" (the Biel remake) and "Wolf Creek," but this flick isn't in the same league as either of those films.  There is absolutely no suspense or really good scares to be found, just lots and lots of formulaic kills and a couple of excellent ones that any gorehound can appreciate.  I also saw a nod to "Friday The 13th" in the plot of the flick.The DVD has some nice extras, especially if you're a wrestling fan.  There are some obvious WWE promos where popular wrestlers such as Chris Benoit and Triple H name their favorite parts of the film and just how much acting Kane really had to do in order to make Jacob Goodnight believable.  There's the obligatory "Making Of" featurette, and a brief videography of Kane's time in the WWF/WWE as well.I understand that a sequel might be in the works.  With the backstory out of the way, perhaps Kane can get to business even sooner, and let the flick be nothing more than a study in gore appreciation.Recommended to gore fans, but if you're looking for any suspense, find something else to watch.

reviewText: See No Evil (Gregory Dark, 2006)That such a thing as "WWE Films" exists is pretty mind-numbing. I had somehow managed to miss that this company, obviously an outlet for films starring professional wrestlers, existed, despite their first two movies having gotten a good bit of publicity (The Rundown and Walking Tall, both starring Dwayne Johnson). However, when See No Evil rolled around, starring a wrestler less known to movie buffs who are not also wrestling fans, the WWE Films logo was a lot more prominent in the advertising. And the idea filled with with something akin to... excitement? Yes, it's true, when I was just a little high-school critic, I used to go see professional wrestling at not-quite-kosher "arenas" in Pittsburgh. I've always kind of liked the theatricality of the thing, though it's gotten way out of hand in recent years. And, I mean, come on, these guys really are actors, albeit more athletic than most. How bad can such a thing really be, especially when you hire porn's most notorious director, Greg Dark (who also directed Britney Spears videos--hmm, same thing, pretty much), to do a horror flick for you?I lay the blame for the abject failure that is See No Evil neither at the feet of Mr. "Let Me Tell Ya 'bout White Chicks" Dark nor those of Glen "Kane" Jacobs, who does an entirely credible job as the serial killer haunting the abandoned hotel. No, the credit for the abject failure that is See No Evil goes entirely to first-time screenwriter Dan Madigan, who is either all too familiar with slasher films and decided not to change a single trope, or is in no way familiar with slasher films, and thinks that he came up with all those tropes on his own (and to be fair, the reason they're now so cliché is because, when people were coming up with them thirty years ago, they were, in fact, pretty damn cool). Either way, the end result is the same; excepting technology improvements, this is a slasher film that could have been made in the late seventies. And actually, given the surfeit of recent remakes of horror films that first came out in the late seventies, this one kind of fits right in, except it's an "original" (I use the term loosely) screenplay.Plot: eight teenagers, two overseers, one serial killer, one abandoned hotel. Do you really need to know any more? There's a lot of teenager-stalking, and the inevitable plot twist, and a bunch of "here's how the killer got this way" flash-back-story that might have been interesting were it not right out of the serial-killing-101 handbook. Really, had there been one deviation from the norm, one slight twist on the usual formula, I probably would have loved this movie. As it stands, however, it's just more of the same in a market that's already supersaturated with more of the same; why bother? **

reviewText: A gory, classic-style 'stalk-and-annihilate' horror movie starring massive pro wrestler Glen 'Kane' Jacobs as silent, hulking psychopath Jacob Goodnight, See No Evil isn't quite the movie it seems to have wanted to be - i.e. it didn't create a new Jason Voorhees/Freddy Krueger-level icon for horror (although who knows what a couple sequels might do?) - but it did create a solid entry into the slash subgenre that fans will certainly want to check out.  Armed with a heavy, hook-ended chain that he swings around to wreak all sorts of carnage; and possessed of a dislike for being looked at, that motivates him to rip victims's eyes out of their sockets, Goodnight is a known serial killer who for the last couple of years has been holed up inside a derelict old building.  When a team of young convicts (mostly low-level crimes, including a cute female animal rights activist arrested for liberating a passel of lab animals; plus a couple of really unlikable nastier criminals) are sent, along with correctional officer chaperones, to the old building to clean it up as part of work release rehabilitation, the building's tenant has a fresh supply of targets.  Also in the mix is the cop who nearly brought Goodnight down a couple of years previous.A bare-bones story is helped along towards the end by flashbacks starting to detail the origins of the Goodnight character, and by some abrupt, and surprisingly effective, swerves in the character's pysche.  There are certainly a few problems with the story.  For starters, only a few of the characters are at all likable, and nobody really seems like they should pose much of a challenge for Jacob.  That's occasionally been a problem in other, similar movies (a couple of the Elm Streets, for example) and they've sometimes gotten around the conundrum of having normal humans stand a chance against an extremely powerful antagonist through a key weakness in the character or through an extremely well-timed convergence of events that opens up an opportunity to level the playing field.  Though a few have been a little too convenient, they've often at least made it plausible that well, yes, if the other guys Did manage to have such a stroke of luck befall them, they really might stand a decent chance.  (And without suddenly making the antagonist look weaker than in the earlier going)  Here though, nothing really adds up with how Goodnight decimates everybody in the first three quarters of the film, and then suddenly he runs into a lot more trouble taking out his victims.  Also, a couple of moments that I think were intended to be humorous fall squarely on their face.  Overall though, "See No Evil" delivers a fine movie with an adequately distinctive - and visually memorable - villain, some very visually memorable female cast members (even though the characterization in some cases could have used work), good special effects, and a good working of angles in the last fifteen minutes or so that, while not a twist ending, suddenly adds a more interesting and tragic aspect to Jacob.  I wouldn't at all mind seeing this story continue on with a sequel or too.  For those who only dip into horror occasionally, See No Evil isn't really the best choice.  But those who love horror movies - especially if that includes ones like Friday The 13th, Nightmare On Elm Street and Texas Chainsaw Massacre - are likely to really enjoy See No Evil despite a couple of shortcomings.

reviewText: Just to let you guys know, I'm a huge horror fan and I like wrestling, so I was very familiar with the Kane character, but I definitely had my doubts about this movie. Movies like these should be no longer than 90 minutes. There just not enough story to stretch out to make it interesting for the audience. The special effects are pretty good for a low budget film like this, though some of the CGI stuff, like the flies, I wasn't particularly fond about. Once again, this movie will probably never be on a list of greatest horror films, and as it shouldn't be. But I say that I have seen much worse low-budget horror films than this one. Heck, there are even a few major released films that weren't as good as this one. The movie probably doesn't deserve 3 stars, so since I can't give it 2.5 stars, I'll be generous. Bascially, if you just want to see a quick-hitting, low-budget horror film with some decent kill scenes in it, this movie is for you.
